sn56.46:1.1: “Mendicants, the boundless desolation of interstellar space is so utterly dark that even the light of the moon and the sun, so mighty and powerful, makes no impression.”
sn56.46:2.1: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
sn56.46:2.2: “Sir, that darkness really is mighty, so very mighty.
sn56.46:2.3: Is there any other darkness more mighty and terrifying than this one?”
sn56.46:3.2: “There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
sn56.46:3.3: They take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth …
sn56.46:3.4: They continue to make such choices …
sn56.46:3.5: Having made such choices, they fall into the darkness of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.46:3.6: They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.46:3.7: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.
sn56.46:4.1: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
sn56.46:4.2: They don’t take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth …
sn56.46:4.4: Having stopped making such choices, they don’t fall into the darkness of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.46:4.5: They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.46:4.6: They’re freed from suffering, I say.
sn56.46:5.1: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
